title: Ticket #6486: Merge python bindings pypi_staging target
description: Wheels for uploading to PyPI can be built using the pypi_build target when using the last couple V8_7_x-pip branches. This build target should be merged into master, if nothing else for automation purposes, but the changes made in [52331] breaks builds of other targets (which build the python bindings). The broken parts should be mostly related to the shifting of code from one file to another, e.g. classad_module.cpp -> _classad_module.cpp.
remarks:
2017-Nov-17 15:38:06 by jpatton:
1. Different linker on more recent Debian (and Debian-based) distros causing problems when building libpyclassad (need to mkdir first? investigating...)

2. get_statistics() in /src/condor_io/reli_sock.cpp references keys in the iperf tcp_info struct that are not provided by the version of iperf in the manylinux docker container:

  • tcpi_rcv_rtt
  • tcpi_rcv_space
  • tcpi_total_retrans

Should we just patch these out when building in a manylinux container? Upgrade iperf in our version of the container? Wait for "manylinux2" ( https://mail.python.org/pipermail/wheel-builders/2017-August/000297.html )?

2017-Nov-20 13:22:03 by jpatton:
The problem with the Debian 8 (and presumably Ubuntu 16) build is in the logic for figuring out the name for libpyclassad in /build/cmake/CondorConfigure.cmake : 

STRING(REGEX REPLACE ".*python([0-9]+[.]?[0-9]+).*" "\\1" _PYTHON_VERSION ${PYTHON_EXECUTABLE})
if ( ${PACKAGE_VERSION} MATCHES "([0-9]+)[.]([0-9]+)[.]([0-9]+)" )
    set( PYCLASSAD_LIB_NAME "pyclassad${_PYTHON_VERSION}_${CMAKE_MATCH_1}_${CMAKE_MATCH_2}_${CMAKE_MATCH_3}" )
    set( UTILS_LIB_NAME "condor_utils_${CMAKE_MATCH_1}_${CMAKE_MATCH_2}_${CMAKE_MATCH_3}" )

For some reason, on Debian 8, ${PYCLASSAD_LIB_NAME} evaluates to:

pyclassad/usr/bin/python_8_7_4

Whereas on CentOS builds, it evaluates to:

pyclassad2.7_8_7_4

2017-Nov-21 12:22:28 by jpatton:
So after more thought and testing, we need to do two things with cmake:

  1. Use a real method (FindPythonInterp, python -V, and/or distutils.sysconfig.version_info) to determine the Python version instead of getting it from the executable name. Even though it's a symlink in Debian 8 and Ubuntu 16, cmake doesn't "see" /usr/bin/python pointing to /usr/bin/python2.7.
  2. Keep pypi_staging (and some of its prereqs) from being built automatically, especially because the bindings aren't built on all platforms (e.g. Fedora) in BaTLab.

2017-Nov-21 13:29:52 by tim:
We should build the python bindings for Fedora. They build them for the Fedora releases of HTCondor.

2017-Nov-21 15:10:08 by jpatton:
cmake seems to need a some hand-holding to find python3 libs and interpreter correctly, e.g.: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29245558/how-to-link-with-python3-libs-with-cmake

Even hardcoding set(Python_ADDITIONAL_VERSIONS 3.5) does not seem to help. Continue to get the output... 

-- Found PythonLibs: /usr/lib64/libpython3.5m.so (found version "3.5.1")
-- Got PYTHONLIBS_VERSION_STRING = 3.5.1
-- Could NOT find PythonInterp: Found unsuitable version "2.7.12", but required is at least "3.5.1" (found /bin/python)
-- Got PYTHON_VERSION_STRING = 2.7.12

...when building on Fedora in BaTLab. Note that this is even with a newer version of cmake (3.6.2 on Fedora 25). It should be finding the interpreter under /bin/python3 or similar.

2017-Nov-29 11:19:21 by jpatton:
I've put the building of the duplicate libraries (_classad and _htcondor) behind an option, WANT_PYTHON_WHEELS, to avoid unnecessary compilation and to prevent strange build errors on Windows. Will hammer away at building on Windows at a later date, but we are not supporting building wheels on Windows right now anyway.

This effect of this change is that HTCondor builds the python bindings (and the rest of the code) as normal, pre-wheel building edits. No build errors on any platform.

2017-Nov-29 15:31:46 by jpatton:
Code merged into master in [52889]. Note that we still need to develop a method of patching reli_sock.cpp to build with older gcc when building the manylinux1 wheels.

2017-Dec-19 11:24:13 by tim:
CODE REVIEW: Looks good. However, please use http://htcondor.org/ as our official web site address.
